Application Summary Pando Climate Co. has published a MIP6 application to introduce rated solar loans from Mosaic Solar, Inc as collateral in the Maker Protocol. This application is initially requesting a $220 million debt ceiling. Pando is built to unleash financing for the age of climate solutions, by tokenizing real world climate assets and offers them as investments. Pando in turn enables protocols and DAO’s to invest in climate solutions, while also stabilizing and growing their treasuries with real-world assets. The MIP6 application is targeted to start its Greenlight polling on 25-July.  Join us Join us 2022-07-19T14:30:00Z as we host: Dori Rutkevitz @Dori - CEO Peter O’Rourke @Peter_Pando - Chief Investment Officer Morgan Wright @MorganPando - CFO If you’re unable to attend this call but have questions: submit any questions for the AMA on this forum post and our hosts will have them addressed during the session.  Agenda    Intro by @juan & @retro  Presentation by the Pando Team Community Q&A   [MIP6]Pando Investment Grade Climate Assets Collateral Onboarding    These rated assets are investment grade that provide the stability and risk profile that the Maker community has signaled a preference for in the past. This Transaction establishes Maker as a peer among blue-chip financial institutions that currently lend to the same type of assets from the same Originator. These institutions include BNP Paribas, New York Life, Royal Bank of Canada, TIAA, PIMCO, Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank, among others. The Pando team is uniquely qualified to invest in, structure, and manage these assets for Maker, and collectively Pando has more than seventy years of experience in energy project finance across more than $70B of projects. This Transaction will enable Maker to diversify its reserves from non-yielding assets to cash flow generating rated assets. Pando and Maker are as aligned as any lender-borrower can be, in that both Pando and Maker’s returns are based on asset performance. Pando did not structure our income as guaranteed fees, which is more typical for this type of transaction. Instead, our return is subordinate to Maker and 100% at risk. Said another way, Pando will not receive its full return unless Maker receives 100% of its return. In that way, Pando is highly motivated to ensure Maker is protected and their loan is fully serviced. content.content: Summary of Terms: (All numbers in brackets refer to sections of the Collateral Application Template] MIP6#: Title: Pando Investment Grade Climate Assets Collateral Onboarding Transaction: Loan to Pando Solar 1 (SPV) to lend against a pool of rated solar loans from Mosaic Solar, Inc. Author(s): Pando Climate Inc. (http://www.pandoclimate.co), a firm of highly experienced energy investors and operators that enables protocols like Maker to benefit from real-world climate assets. Contributors: Dan Rosen, Dori Rutkevitz, Peter O’Rourke, Morgan Wright Type: Proposal Initial Debt Ceiling: ~$220 Million 12 month goal: >$1 Billion Transaction Terms* [31]:  image1282×559 75.4 KB  Status: Date Proposed: <2022-07-06> Forum URL: […]  References  Mosaic Surpasses $6 Billion in Loans Project Real World Sandbox MIP67: Methodology and Review Process for Structured Finance Transactions Methodology for Review of MIP6 Structured Finance Transactions KBRA Global Rating Methodology KBRA Structured Finance Counterparty Methodology KBRA ESG Global Rating Methodology SES Project Real-World Sandbox IPCC Sixth Assessment Report   Executive Summary [2]  767×432 680 KB  MIP6: Pando Climate Inc. (“Pando”) is offering Investment Grade solar assets to MakerDAO (“Maker”). This will enable Maker to earn stable, risk-adjusted financial returns, in a market currently dominated by top-tier global institutions, all while backing climate-positive collateral that prevents greenhouse gas emissions. Some climate investments make dubious claims regarding their financial returns, their climate impact (e.g., some carbon credits have controversy surrounding the quality of their verification standards) or both. This first transaction represents rooftop solar systems on U.S. homes: these systems provide contracted cash flows from customers, and prevent greenhouse gas emissions, often helping homeowners save money every month while meaningfully changing their relationship with their own energy generation. Pando believes there is a profound opportunity to use DeFi to accelerate climate solutions while providing stable risk-adjusted returns to investors. This transaction does not subsidize climate, rather enters Maker into an existing marketplace that currently is dominated by top-tier TradFi investors. These investors lend to Mosaic because of the stable, investment-grade cashflows, the diversification provided against other stable investments (e.g., Treasuries), and attractive risk-adjusted returns. The high demand also means there typically are ready buyers for these loans should Maker need to unwind and liquidate its position. Asset [6, 7]: The first opportunity that Pando is offering to Maker is to lend~$220M against a ~$250M pool of rated solar loans (the “Transaction”). The assets supporting the Maker loan are contracted cash flows from PV Solar installations on residential rooftops. The Transaction is highly structured, and the pool of solar loans will be rated Investment Grade by a US Credit Rating agency (Kroll Bond Rating Agency, or KBRA). As a result of this Transaction, the company originating the loans will be able to increase its deployment of solar. Also, the Transaction provides Maker with an opportunity to earn yield from assets that are uncorrelated with the rest of the crypto market, while demonstrating how cryptocurrencies can pioneer innovative, cost-competitive financing structures in clean energy. Maker will be in the senior secured position, providing significant protection in any downside scenarios. Maker will fund the ~$220m as part of a single Tranche at closing for the Transaction (e.g., a static Pool). Unlike some bond offerings (e.g., US Treasuries) that only return principal at maturity, both principal and interest payments for the Transaction will commence directly after closing. This Transaction will not tokenize the solar loans, and as a result Pando will coordinate with the Real World Assets Team on a MIP21.  Treasuries vs. Loans In some Forum posts, we have noted that the Community is debating investing in Treasuries vs. in real-world assets.  While an Investment Grade transaction like this presents minimal risk similar to Treasuries, most investors diversify their portfolio by having a mix of investments that include both investment grade rated assets as well as Treasuries.  While there are several reasons to diversify investments, a primary reason to invest in instruments other than Treasuries is Treasuries pay interest only until the maturity of the note, meaning all principal on a ten year note is outstanding for the full ten years. Conversely, private loans return Principal and Interest immediately, offering investors more flexibility and liquidity with their capital.  Below please find a simple representation of cumulative Principal & Interest payments for the Pando Transaction vs a ten year UST. For example, the Pando Transaction will return $133M by the end of year five (including $115M of returned principal) versus only $30M in interest payments from the UST (with no principal).  854×568 13.4 KB   Market Pricing Also, at Maker RWA CU’s request, we confirmed with two investment banks (Royal Bank of Canada & Citibank) that the pricing offered by Mosaic is consistent with currently priced solar bonds in the market.  While the proposed Pando assets are not solar bonds, the CUs requested that we use these assets as a comparable, since solar loans are not publicly traded.  Both RBC and Citi confirmed that the pricing offered by Mosaic is indeed either at par or higher than what they would expect to see currently in the market. This MIP6 also details strict conditions for the setup of the underlying legal and governance structure and attestation requirements. This proposal contemplates the use of a Delaware Statutory Trust and the creation of bankruptcy-remote SPVs to provide the necessary legal protections for all participants. Other items to note include:  These rated assets are investment grade that provide the stability and risk profile that the Maker community has signaled a preference for in the past. This Transaction establishes Maker as a peer among blue-chip financial institutions that currently lend to the same type of assets from the same Originator. These institutions include BNP Paribas, New York Life, Royal Bank of Canada, TIAA, PIMCO, Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank, among others. The Pando team is uniquely qualified to invest in, structure, and manage these assets for Maker, and collectively Pando has more than seventy years of experience in energy project finance across more than $70B of projects. This Transaction will enable Maker to diversify its reserves from non-yielding assets to cash flow generating rated assets. Pando and Maker are as aligned as any lender-borrower can be, in that both Pando and Maker’s returns are based on asset performance. Pando did not structure our income as guaranteed fees, which is more typical for this type of transaction. Instead, our return is subordinate to Maker and 100% at risk. Said another way, Pando will not receive its full return unless Maker receives 100% of its return. In that way, Pando is highly motivated to ensure Maker is protected and their loan is fully serviced. Maker may benefit from the increasing regulatory pressure from the White House, SEC, the UN, and others to dramatically advance the clean energy economy.  “President Biden knows that we need to move even faster to combat climate change…reaching 100% carbon pollution-free electricity by 2035 ”  White House, February 28, 2022   “The SEC Will Regulate Climate”  Bloomberg News, March 22, 2022       Answers to criteria areas provided by RWF CU. [1, 3, 4, 5, 8, 9, 12, 13, 17, 22-27, 30 34: Not applicable]  Background of Asset Manager (Pando) & Key Member’s Historical Performance Demand for solar energy has been increasing exponentially as the cost to install solar continues to drop. According to a recent UN study, we need to deploy $2 trillion annually to meet climate targets by the end of the decade. While climate technology has been proven to work and the demand is there, traditional financial institutions are not responsive enough to keep up with the growing demand. Pando believes MakerDAO and other crypto protocols can be a critical player in accelerating the adoption of climate solutions globally while earning a stable return. Pando was created in early 2022 by the founder and former-CEO of Solar Mosaic, Inc. (Mosaic) and the former product lead at Mosaic, which has financed more than $7B of solar loans and issued several billion (USD) in rated solar debt instruments. Pando’s four principals have decades of combined experience in energy finance and have collectively structured or participated in more than $70B of energy projects. Highlights of Pando’s Principals include:  Founding team of Mosaic, Navajo Power  Senior leadership at US Department of Energy’s Loan Programs Office  $60B in total energy loans across wind, solar, geothermal, EVs, and nuclear $465M loan to Tesla, the catalyst for the Model S $2.6B distributed generation project, first ever for Bank of America and a leading Real Estate Investment Trust   Created, deployed, and managed a ~$500M, SEC-registered solar tax equity Investment Advisory firm Senior leadership at New Energy Nexus, Core Capital, Sparkfund, and other leading energy/finance companies  [36] The Pando principals are supported by world class Advisors, including KPMG (tax), as well as Perkins Coie, and Morrison & Foerster (legal). Pando’s mission is to radically accelerate the flow of capital into climate solutions by bringing high-quality climate assets to crypto protocols. Pando’s Role in Transaction: Briefly below is a high-level description of Pando’s role, which is based on our decades of experience in this sort of transaction. Pando’s net yield is low compared to what a typical borrower and sponsor would expect for this sort of transaction, in particular as it is structured as an at-risk Yield vs. a guaranteed Fee. Pando accepts this lower return given the competitive nature of the transaction does not leave much room for a larger return, and Pando hopes this to be the first of many Maker transactions.  Structuring the project and managing all pre-close activities, including but not limited to: Kroll rating, SocGen structuring, Mosaic tranche verification, and Pando credit underwriting. Pando (via a specially established Borrower entity) will be the borrower counterparty to Maker. That same borrower will also be the Lender to Mosaic. Pando (the parent company) will be responsible for the following activities:  Managing all 3rd party servicer providers, including managing the Servicer to ensure principal & interest payments and all fee balances are flowing appropriately to the Payment Agent. Managing the Payment Agent to ensure principal & interest payments and all fees are properly distributed, in accordance with the Loan Agreement (including the cash Waterfall). Coordinating with Maker’s Trustee (US) to ensure all payments are received from Payment Agent, and then all principal and interest payments are distributed to Maker’s overseas Trust. As requested by Maker, coordinate with Marker’s overseas Trustee to ensure it has all relevant information so that it can ensure all distributions to Maker are handled appropriately. (Note: Both Maker Trustees will not be directed by Pando, rather Pando is solely a supporting party.) Monitoring portfolio performance and addressing actual and potential risks to the portfolio performance. Reporting on portfolio performance to Maker. Exercising any and all remedies articulated in the Mosaic-Pando Loan Agreement in the event of default and/or any other event that is addressed in the Loan Agreement.    Conflicts of Interest:  Pando is unaware of any real or potential conflicts of interest with Maker or any Maker-related affiliate.  Pando hereby discloses that Dan Rosen, co-Founder of Pando, currently is Chairman of the Mosaic Board of Directors. Process for Changing Investment Guidelines & Policies:  Importantly, as this Transaction is a single, one-time transaction, any subsequent changes to Pando’s or Maker’s Investment Guidelines and Policies would not affect this Transaction.  If Maker chooses to continue with additional capital allocations to transactions with similar terms (e.g., increasing the debt ceiling past the initial Transaction), Pando will provide Maker with clear indications of any changes to its investment processes, guidelines, and policies when proposing debt ceiling increases. Process for Transitioning to Another Asset Manager: If Pando ceases to exist or otherwise exits this transaction, Maker is protected via the terms and structure of the Loan Agreement that will be entered into between the parties.  Using a traditional, common structure for project or ABS transactions, Maker would be able to take over the Pando borrowing entity (“Pando SPV”), a bankruptcy-remote special purpose vehicle.  This SPV structure allows Maker and/or any affiliate to ensure the cash flows coming from the loan to Pando continue to perform and are serviced, with little to no interruption. Asset Manager’s Business Model: Pando principals are experienced as lenders, including managing project finance loans that require an active lender.  While this initial Transaction proposed to Maker is more simple, it still requires a lender who is actively monitoring project performance on a monthly basis and is willing to take the liabilities, representations, covenants, and credit obligations for this transaction.  Also, in distress situations, an active lender is required to step in to evaluate and exercise all rights and remedies. Pando performs this role as lender, as it is not the purpose of a DST to be a direct lender.  Wilmington Trust or any other similar entity is not experienced or staffed to serve in this role, nor do we presume they would take on this role.  There are obligations and liabilities, including credit obligations, that are counter to the legal requirements and obligations of a Trust participating as an impartial collateral agent. We believe there is no bankruptcy risk to the Pando SPV in the proposed structure.  Our structure is a well-established, traditional project finance structure, specifically designed to manage parent company/holdco risks.  The Pando SPV will be a bankruptcy-remote entity that is established for the sole purpose of lending to Mosaic. Maker’s capital is not at risk even if Pando Climate Inc., disappears. If Pando were to disappear, the Pando SPV would continue to operate, but could be taken over by Maker, who then would coordinate with another provider to manage the remaining term of the loan. This hypothetical situation may create operational issues for the DST, but it does not jeopardize Maker’s capital or yield. Similarly, the Mosaic-Pando Loan Agreement will be between Pando SPV & Mosaic SPV, so that if Mosaic disappears, Pando would be able to take over that Mosaic SPV and ensure the loans continue to perform and be serviced. Pando & Mosaic Risk Mitigation Processes: Rating Agency and Asset Manager Underwriting [32, 33] Both Mosaic and Pando have best-in-class underwriting processes. For example, Mosaic spent years establishing a public rating methodology with Kroll Bond Rating Agency. An Investment Grade rating signifies the risk of default in the underlying assets is extremely unlikely. Also, Pando utilizes a Risk Underwriting Model against which the Principals have developed and deployed billions of dollars. The Pando model has been reviewed by public accounting firms and institutional investors - all of whom have declared it best-in-class. KBRA will analyze the pool of solar loans in the Transaction using the General Global Rating Methodology for Asset-Backed Securities and the Consumer Loan ABS Global Rating Methodology, as well as its Global Structured Finance Counterparty Methodology and ESG Global Rating Methodology. The Transaction falls within the “Category 1 – Financial Assets” categorization noted within the Global General Rating Methodology for Asset-Backed Securities, which typically relates to transactions that are backed by pools of consumer or commercial financial obligations owed by diverse obligors. In applying these methodologies, KBRA analyzes the Transaction’s data and the underlying collateral pool and analyzes the capital structure using stressed cash flow assumptions. Pando and its legal counsel also will review operative agreements and legal opinions prior to closing. The following table provides a summary description of the underwriting criteria that Pando uses to evaluate distributed generation assets like the Transaction.  Each category has multiple subcategories and percentage valuations, and scores are assigned for each subcategory in order to comprehensively evaluate the creditworthiness of the project.  1280×596 28.7 KB  [35] For this Transaction, Pando’s underwriting process is secondary to Kroll’s rating process. A KBRA rating is sufficient for most lenders, and the Pando principals have relied on similar ratings for other transactions. However, as a matter of practice, Pando will always run projects through our underwriting process as a matter of good internal governance. Background of the Originator (Mosaic) [21]  741×432 399 KB  The pool of solar loans that comprise the Transaction are originated by Mosaic, one of the most respected climate finance companies in the world. Mosaic has originated more than $7 billion in loans since June 2014. It is a California-based specialist finance company that enables homeowners to go solar by providing them a loan to cover the cost of solar installation. Often, homeowners save money because their monthly solar loan payments are cheaper than their previous utility bills. This Investment Grade Solar Transaction represents a diversified portfolio of loans (across thousands of U.S. homeowners), all enabling decentralized renewable energy generation. If this proposal is approved, this capital will allow Mosaic to deploy even more residential solar in the U.S. Mosaic originates loans to mostly prime credit quality homeowners through its partnerships with more than 700 approved solar system installers/dealers. Mosaic disburses funds directly to installers, equal to the system cost minus installer discounts. This discount depends on the loan term and dealer agreements and is generally netted out proportionately with each disbursement to the installer/dealer. Mosaic directly originates loans in 48 states and the District of Columbia through its state lending licenses where required, and across all 50 states and the District of Columbia through lending partnerships with financial institutions. The following bullets detail additional information about Mosaic:  Mosaic has issued loans to partners like Tesla, SunRun and SunPower. Current loan purchasers are publicly traded financial institutions (e.g., BNP Paribas, New York Life, Royal Bank of Canada, TIAA, PIMCO, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, etc.). Pando & Maker will lend similarly to these institutions. Homeowner owns/maintains the system and makes payments against the loan. Mosaic pools loans into a ‘warehouse’ facility; those pools are then formed into tranches that receive a Kroll rating based on an established underwriting methodology Mosaic bundles and sells solar loans to financial institutions. This method represents an efficient, cost-effective way to capitalize Mosaic. Selling to these institutions allows Mosaic to deploy even more solar.  Reporting [34] The Asset Manager will rely on Mosaic’s existing reporting systems, methods, and technologies to update Maker on the performance of the underlying pool of assets. Reporting will be provided monthly and will include:  Account reconciliations, including the Reserve account, Collections account, and Capitalized Interest account; Pool Information, including average coupon, remaining term, aggregate principal balance, and number of loans active; Collections, distributions, and fees paid in period; Delinquency Rates; Cumulative default history; Cumulative Net losses; Recoveries against defaults; and Prepayment Information.   Transaction Structure [15, 15, 16] The proposed structure is a private, rated back-to-back loan, not a public bond purchase with different tiers of risk priced differently (the latter being Mosaic’s typical bond financing structure). First, Mosaic will work with Soc Gen and Kroll to combine a group of loans that together have a weighted average FICO score of 700 or greater and a combined default risk consistent with a BBB+ rating. Kroll will issue a private rating of BBB+ on that pool of loans. Not every loan within the pool will carry that rating, as the rating is on the blended pool. Then, Pando proposes that Maker lends capital in one tranche to a Pando SPV whose sole purpose is to lend against the cash flows from that entire contemplated pool of loans from Mosaic. Every dollar that is lent to the Pando SPV from Maker will be used to complete the Transaction. The Pando SPV will be the counterparty to Maker on one side, and the Pando SPV will be the counterparty to Mosaic on the other side. The loan from the Pando SPV to Mosaic will be secured by all of the underlying loans in the rated pool of assets. For the loan from Maker to Pando, the security interest will be in the Pando SPV – with all of the Pando SPV’s rights extending to Maker via the Pando-Maker Loan Agreement. The structure is similar to how lending institutions operate today, borrowing from the Fed at the Cost of Funds and then lending to customers at a higher rate. Similarly, we propose borrowing from Maker and behaving as many similar financial institutions do so today. The weighted average interest rate on the aforementioned A-D tranches of the 2022-1 Mosaic offering was 2.91%. Mosaic and Kroll present IRR as yield, which will be higher than the interest rate as some prepayments push up the IRR calculation on the portfolio from the paid interest rate. Similarly, the IRR Maker will receive will be higher than the interest rate offered (currently 2.00%).  Full or partial pre-payments typically are seen as a result of homeowners receiving the ITC (Federal tax credit for solar) or when a homeowner sells their house (and the new owner chooses not to assume the loan). If a homeowner were to refinance their mortgage, they have the option of prepaying the solar loan in its entirety or continuing with the original amortization schedule; extension of the loan is not an option for homeowners. We have negotiated with Mosaic for the proposed Transaction to be priced above the interest rate (~2.90%) of the entire 2022-1 Mosaic transaction. They have agreed to a yield of 4.25%, which brings the underlying interest rate closer to 3.45%, depending on prepayment activity. Any difference between estimated and actual fees paid to the Collateral Agent and Mosaic as Servicer can also flow to Maker, and we are willing to discuss ways to include additional reserves and/or refining some of the ongoing cost assumptions. The following bullets provide some of the benefits that will accrue to Maker from the Transaction.  The Transaction will generate a stable return to Maker from climate-focused, highly-structured, rated cash flowing assets. These assets are not correlated to the crypto market. Unlike a purchase of Treasury Bills, this Transaction will have a scheduled payment of principal and interest to Maker on either a monthly or quarterly basis. The technology used for the solar systems is commercial grade with substantial warranties for design, workmanship, and installation. The Transaction poses no technology risk for Maker. The structure of the Transaction is repeatable, and significant demand exists for similar transactions. The Pando principals are confident they can structure several billions in similar transactions once the template is complete with this Transaction. While the Transaction will have a private rating of Investment Grade, there may be an ability to increase the returns from projects with different risk profiles in future transactions. The Pando team is deeply experienced in sourcing, diligencing, structuring, and managing similar assets to the Transaction. The Transaction is novel as it will be the first funded by a cryptocurrency, solidifying MakerDAO as the pioneer of a new financing structure for renewable energy. This structure allows DAI to be backed by “clean”, stable cash flows from renewable assets.   Legal and Approval Structure Verification [10, 11, 29] This proposal is based on the precedents set by the 6S Trust structure approved by the community in MIP13c3-SP4, as well MIP21, which has been active for more than six months. Pando will cover Maker’s legal costs (with a mutually agreed cap) to execute on the Pando-Maker loan agreement, the Kroll rating, setting up the DST, and other agreed upon expenses. Pando has a signed term sheet with Mosaic, and we have been waiting for initial indications from Maker to proceed with the Mosaic-Pando Loan Agreement. That agreement will be based on Mosaic’s precedent loan agreements, meaning there will be limited initial drafting.  We are able to start that loan agreement negotiation with Mosaic at any point.  Our plan is to create a reasonably final draft, and then coordinate with Maker & Maker’s Counsel to ensure that major terms are agreeable to Maker.  That process will allow for significant coordination and will ensure that the back-to-back loans are agreeable to all parties. The legal structure is designed to include these characteristics:  This is a single Transaction, not a series of transactions. Therefore, there is no ability to change the terms once the Transaction is complete. Principal (the borrowed amount) and interest will be paid to Maker on a monthly basis. Interest will be paid to the Maker Protocol surplus buffer, while Principal will be returned to the Maker vault. Third parties will not have access to the funds or be able to change the terms or legal structure. It should not be possible for a third party to block Maker Governance’s ability to make decisions or modify the structure. There must be no ability for funds to be misappropriated or get stuck. Details on how to deal with an Emergency Shutdown will be developed and incorporated during the development process of this proposal.  This established structure requires a relationship with a regulated crypto broker, and an immutable ETH address must be emitted that can be used to construct the smart contracts necessary to complete the technical step of the onboarding process specified in MIP6XX. The following slides demonstrate the detailed flow of funds (DAI and USD), as well as the legal entities and approvals.  Pando will work with the Real World Asset Team to ensure the Transaction remains consistent with the 6S Trust Structure, and that the protections for Maker are clear and strong. A high level summary of the transaction is below.  800×450 200 KB  The following section summarizes the responsibilities of the primary parties to the Transaction:  800×450 198 KB  Maker Trustee  Delaware (DE) Statutory Trust - (for example, Wilmington Trust) Independent, 3rd party Ensures all capital flows are approved and accurate The Maker Trustee confirms that the Transaction meets all requirements and that all Conditions Precedent (CPs) have been satisfied prior to execution. The Maker Trustee also provides irrevocable instructions to Pando on whether and when to fund the Transaction.  Maker Foundation Company:  Entity that will be the conduit for funds from Maker Vault through to the Delaware Statutory Trust. Exact entity structure (e.g., Trust, or Foundation, etc.) will be confirmed and established in conversation with the Maker Real World Assets Team.  Pando  Serves as Lender to Mosaic Structures, approves, and manages the Transaction. Confirms all Conditions Precedent have been met prior to funding Mosaic loan. Manages the Servicer, oversees all loans, and remedies any issues. Ensures the entire structure is compliant with tax and accounting regulations.   Capital Flows:  Maker(Cayman Trust) - Maker (DST): We presume these flows will operate similar to any other trust contribution where assets are placed into trust.  Mechanically, the Cayman Trustee would presumably set up a wallet it controls (either exclusively or with some form of multi-signature for security purposes) that is not commingled with any other digital assets.  Maker’s Cayman Trust agreement would dictate that any tokens placed into that specific wallet from time to time are to be held in trust, so that the blockchain transfer into that specific wallet would be the operative evidence of the formal change in record title to the tokens as assets held in trust. Many, within the community, have asked for my opinion regarding Pando’s MIP6 for Investment Grade Climate Assets Collateral Onboarding submitted by @Dori. Without any intention to make of this a comprehensive overview (I am neither tasked nor compensated to provide such a deal review) I would like to stress a few points based on my professional experience. Those represent uniquely my personal opinions as member of the community. I would like to focus on the bond vs. loan pricing point that has been debated at length. I have read many comments on pricing coming from qualified community members - including @Eumenes, @teej, and @dbkcan - I am giving more weight to those coming from Eric and TJ given their direct mandate as members of RWF. Those comments stress the need to benchmark Pando’s proposed deal with available comparables in the public market. Although relevant, I do not think that those public comps are the most relevant decision making levers for MKR holders. When assessing a loan and its pricing, a bank’s Credit Committee typically analyses the opportunity through internal metrics of return. Although external benchmarks are useful, it is ultimately the projected (e.g.) Return on Equity for the lender that is the most relevant data point for decision making. The projected Return on Equity is achieved using as inputs the agreed pricing, but also internal estimates about cost and risk items. As an example, those parameters would include: i) expected loss on the underlying collateral, ii) cost of liquidity, iii) risk capital absorption, iv) cost of capital, v) infrastructural costs and overheads. Without a holistic overview of what is the projected net return for Maker, discussions on pricing and spreads are not entirely relevant. Especially considering the totally different characteristics of the two instruments. To stress the point further, also considering @Eumenes’ concerns on mark-to-market and Maker’s de facto insolvency vs. the existing Surplus Buffer, I would like to confirm that in bank accounting, while a bond might be typically booked as an Available For Sale security (with mark-to-market hitting a dedicated equity reserve that is indeed deducted from regulatory capital), a loan would be simply part of the loan book and would not be impaired unless significant credit quality events happen. A loan, in addition, benefits from completely different accounting and regulatory treatments. This is why not necessarily a loan would trade at discount vs. a bond because of its illiquid nature. Obviously, in the case the loans/ collaterals would need to be sold for liquidity purposes, Maker should expect to receive a significant haircut on the book. It is, however, absolutely not prudent to engage in such a long-dated transaction considering the possibility to sell the book outright a central scenario. This should be solely an emergency and ALM/ Strategic Finance/ @SebVentures should provide comfort on size and duration without considering a normal scenario that of collateral disposal. This is an illiquid position, and as such it should be treated. Ultimately, as a Maker community member, I would expect to receive at least the following information to help me take a decision:  Guidance on available size for duration buckets for those RWF deals - most probabily coming from SF Guidance on required / target Return on Equity on those transactions - I guess under SF’s leadership Framework that would allow RWF and SF to achieve an estimate of the Return on Equity for each deal - including the most relevant components Estimate of the Return on Equity of a single deal based on the current proposed pricing Detail on cash flows and other characteristics provided by the counterparty  Although I am generally in agreement that Pando’s proposal might not be optimal for Maker, I do not think that Maker’s Core Units are providing the necessary frameworks at this stage to help MKR holders assess the opportunity. Personally, it is the lack of junior capital that is my main concern - given that foregone interests in case of bad performance resemble more the cost of a call option rather than junior equity in a deal, but this is a different conversation. For the avoidance of the doubt, I am not in disagreement with what has been pointed out by the CU members, but I believe that the lack of framework to assess opportunities one against the other is making impossible for MKR holders to take an informed decision on this (and other) MIPs. As @rune suggested, I would be extremely interested in listening to @BlockTower’s opinion; the perspective of a private credit investor should resemble that of a private lender. Thank you for the thoughtful MIP6, Pando! It’s great to see a team with such deep experience working to partner with Maker and onboard high-quality assets. Below, I have listed a set of Merits and Concerns that we (BlockTower, collectively) have compiled after reviewing this investment. Merits High quality solar loans – Mosaic has a deep underwriting history with studied performance data across a host of market conditions. In addition, Mosaic targets a high-quality segment of the consumer credit universe. Borrowers are homeowners with FICO scores deep in the 700s. Available pricing data – Mosaic’s utilization of the securitization market has, amongst other benefits, introduced a moderate level of pricing transparency to this space and increased broader familiarity to the asset class. Pricing transparency is helpful for underwriting the merits of this investment and broader familiarity helps to facilitate liquidity in the space. BBB+ Kroll Rating – Self-explanatory, an investment grade rating is representative of a pool that is likely to meet interest and principal payments. Reliable Servicing – Mosaic is a mature business with deep industry experience. The corporate entity is unlikely to default and thus likely to be able to service these loans through maturity. In addition, there are capable backup servicers available should Mosaic default. Concerns Long Duration – This investment has a term maturity of 14 years and a WAL of 6 years (to assumed prepayment assumptions). Should underlying credit performance deteriorate, there is no imminent solution available to unwind the structure. Additionally, all else equal, long duration assets take greater mark-to-market losses in periods of volatility than do short duration assets. If a liquidation is necessary, we need to consider the likelihood that the catalyst for liquidation will correspond to a broader credit sell-off that impairs Maker’s ultimate recovery. Lack of Junior Capital – While we understand that Pando is placing its fees below Maker in this structure, we do not believe this is a true substitute for traditional first loss capital. If the Maker position takes a loss, Pando will simply lose out on future fee income. A true first loss capital provider will lose out on future earnings as well as investment capital put at risk. Additionally, in the event of a liquidation, a first loss capital provider has a clear incentive to maximize recovery on the underlying pool; a first loss capital provider will be seeking to maximize recovery for both itself and for Maker. It’s unclear what Pando’s incentive is to maximize recovery in a liquidation scenario. Pando team, I have listed a few questions below. We would greatly appreciate your thoughts and considerations here. Questions Is it possible to add in performance triggers that will allow Maker to initiate a liquidation or acceleration? [This is particularly important with the lack of junior capital, given there is no junior noteholder to initiate a liquidation on behalf of Maker]. Perhaps some form of cumulative net-loss trigger that is tripped when realized losses escalate? In the event of a liquidation, would Pando sell the underlying loans outright or would Pando seek to sell just Maker’s senior loan? In other words, would Pando’s fees and Mosaic’s residual interest survive a liquidation?

Additionally, to address concerns around pricing directly, it is our opinion that the securitization/whole loan markets are the best available proxy for pricing. There are many market participants (banks, asset managers, credit unions, etc.) who buy whole loans via forward flow arrangements with the intention of securitizing once loans reach a critical mass. As a rule, whole loans trade at a discount to ABS securitizations because they are less liquid and do not have locked in term financing. Based on an ongoing dialogue with Citi’s ABS and whole loan desks, solar loans generically trade at a 5% yield today. Pando’s proposal indicates that the yield on the Mosaic note will be roughly 3%. Clearly this is off market for whole loans. Thus, it is worth thinking about whether the added subordination that Pando is proposing justifies that 2% gap vs. whole loan pricing. In our opinion, it is tough to justify this gap when the most senior piece of solar securitizations, which has more downside protection, yields 5%.

Additionally, in the event of a liquidation, a first loss capital provider has a clear incentive to maximize recovery on the underlying pool; a first loss capital provider will be seeking to maximize recovery for both itself and for Maker. It’s unclear what Pando’s incentive is to maximize recovery in a liquidation scenario   We believe there has been a misunderstanding on our MIP6 and perhaps we haven’t communicated this well in the past: there is a substantial junior position in the asset pool, in addition to a pre-funded Debt Service Reserve Account of 1% of the pool (~$2.5M). And, Pando’s net yield is available to service Maker’s payments in the event the junior position is eroded. To put this into perspective, Kroll typically triples the number of defaults for a rating as part of their modeling; in this case, BBB+ asset pools typically default at a rate of 14 customers annually, and Kroll models 50 defaults annually.
